entry.title: 5 Ways to Save Money While Living Energy Efficiently in Your Home
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

What would you do with a couple extra hundred dollars? A couple extra thousand? Imagine having the fun of thinking about this after making some minor changes in your home that would allow you to save money all year around. Here are five easy ways you can make changes in your home – you won’t believe how much money you’ll end up saving!

Check Your Toilets for Leaks
So many toilets leak from one place or the other but most consumers have no idea how much money they are literally flushing down the drain every year. That is why it’s important to check for leaks. The easiest way to do this is to put in some food coloring in your water tank and then flush the toilet. See the dye anywhere that it’s not supposed to go? You have a problem and you ought to get it fixed right away. You can lose up to 200 gallons of water each day with a leaky toilet and that adds up to about $400 each year that you could be saving!

Use a Surge Protector
Not only will you have the protection you get during a storm from a surge protector, by plugging in all your major electronics and similar appliances into one of these things makes it easy for you to turn it all off when you’re not using them. Going on vacation? Switch it off. Heading out to work? Same thing. The savings can be up to $500 a year just from not needing to provide power to these electronics, even if they are not turned on.

Control Incoming Sunlight
A lot of people with windows that face the south have to deal with extra sunlight filtering in their homes. The fix for that is an easy one. Simply buy reflecting films for windows that are designed to block up to 70% of the sun’s rays from entering your domain. This really becomes useful during those long, hot summer days and other warm months of the year.

Install Energy Efficient Windows and Doors
The best thing you can do for long-term savings and overall comfort of your home is to change over to single or better yet double pane windows with high Energy Star efficiency ratings. Here’s how Energy Star ratings work. The savings add up quickly for those homeowners changing from double pane windows that weren’t up to par at $250 a year and with new double pane windows you will save as much as $500 each year!

Switch Over to Dimmers
Believe it or not, when you change your light switches to the kind that have dimmers you actually end up saving a good amount of energy. Since these switches offer flexibility a simple change of dimming the lights down just 30% will yield you about 24% savings in your electricity bill every single year. Imagine that.

~
The savings are stacking up – so much that it looks like you could even get a family vacation in for the amount you will save from these updates to your home. And if you’re looking to sell your home, all these things will put you at a great advantage over the competition. If you need help with anything real estate related, please contact us at 502.376.5483 and we’d be happy to oblige!

link.title: 5 Ways to Save Money While Living Energy Efficiently in Your Home

entry.title: Real Estate Market Trends
entry.content:
Watch on Your Mobile Device >>

As I filmed the video for this blog post straight from the heart of Las Vegas, I could not help but to bask in the hustle and bustle of America’s favorite place to play. Well, just like Vegas – our real estate market has had a lot of activity lately too and the news is still good.

Our team had the good fortune to talk with Steven Harney, notable real estate expert and founder of Keeping Current Matters – a top real estate blog with the latest information on trends and statistics.

Here’s what we can look forward to in the coming months and ahead…

Buyers Will Continue to Enjoy Low, Low Rates
Unlike anything any of us have ever seen, the country’s lowest interest rates on record are still going strong. At the same time the prices have not even come close to where they were just six years ago. That means that buyers are getting more for the money and it is costing them less to own their properties.

Sellers Gaining Ground – Prices Stable but Will Rise Over Time
The big news for sellers these days is that more and more buyers are vying for their properties, trying to take advantage of the amazing interest rates. As a result, we are seeing multiple offers and in some markets there are bidding wars happening.

Prices Still Need Time To Reach Pre-2007 Levels
In terms of pricing, there is some promising news. Though the projected rise in prices to pre-2007 levels does not occur until at least 2016, we can hope to expect a slow but steady increase in values over the next several years. The Home Price Expectation Survey, Urban Land Institute and Demand Institute Study – all report a modest but consistent trend toward increasing home prices. At the Editor’s Conference in Denver the Chief Economist with the National Association of Realtors, Lawrence Yun, recently said that by this time next year there could be a 10% price appreciation in some cities.

There is no way to tell exactly when and how prices will go up, but the news is certainly promising.  Once we go through our existing inventory we will be in a better position to gauge the distant future of housing values in our area. For now though, home prices in Louisville are starting to come back and there has been a lot of activity in terms of home sales.
~
If you want to find out what the price of your home is, let us know. We’ll do a CMA and we’ll come over, take a look at your home and evaluate what we think you might be able to get for your home.

If you want to list, we’re ready to help you. If you want to buy – we are on board. If you know someone that needs guidance or assistance, we are right here waiting and ready to help out anyone that needs it. Contact us today at 502 376 5483 – we look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: Adding Curb Appeal Through Landscaping Part 2
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Feeling the urge to brighten up your lawn and garden space?  Well you picked a great year to do it!  This year, the up and coming trends in lawn and garden have been dominated by the use of LOTS of color!  Whether in the plants used to beautify your landscape, flowers that blanket a shaded area in the garden or the myriad accessories you place in the space, color is EVERYWHERE!

We took a trip to our local greenhouse to find out what everyone’s buying this year and how these homeowners are decorating their outdoor spaces. And whether you are looking to sell your home or just want to be the “best kid on the block”, this is good information.

Bright, Vibrant Hues

Nothing brightens up an outdoor space more than the gorgeous reds, yellows, pinks, purples and bright blues that we are seeing in many gardens these days. The flowering plants are flying off shelves this spring and summer and for good reason. Add in some multi-shaded greenery and the entire space feels like a warm and inviting lush tropical garden.

Mix and Match Flowers

Gone are the days when an entire flowerbed would have matching hues and similarly styled plants. The new trend is to load up the area with a mishmash of interesting colors, shapes and sizes – with a splash of topography in there as well. Planting flowers with varying heights will add visual interest beyond just the already eye-popping colors immediately visible in the garden.
Large geraniums are 30” tall and bright while periwinkles offer substantial ground cover and visual interest at the same time at 10” tall.

Eclectic Accessorizing

Bright colors are not limited only to flowers and plants. In fact, the new trend is to infuse brightness into all accessories as well. Bring in several different color pots and accessories for your outdoor space. Not only do they complement the plants and flowers they also give the space an eclectic charm.

Personality Punch in Outdoor Linens

Many retailers are stocking ethnic prints with splashes of color and pattern to enhance your outdoor space and add some pizazz to outdoor furniture. We are also seeing some animal prints, geometric patterns and bold stripes added to the mix of today’s selection. Adding your own personality is key – just as you would to your indoor areas.
~
As a homeowner looking to sell, if you are looking to attract attention to your home, look no further than today’s outdoor trends. Remember, the key is personality. As potential buyers drive by and are warmly inviting into your space because of a great outdoor area that feels like an oasis – of course they will want to see more of where that came from!

link.title: Adding Curb Appeal Through Landscaping Part 2

entry.title: No-Hassle Curb Appeal For People That Don’t Have Lots of Time
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Home sellers these days have a lot of things to contend with. For starters, there are a lot more homes for sale than there have been in years past. Second, unless the property is absolutely gorgeous the homeowner will need to do something to attract attention and entice buyers to come in.

Like the old adage says, “the first impression is the last impression” and it has a lot of weight when it comes to selling a home. Of course we have all seen those TV shows that depict expert gardeners spending hours, days and maybe even weeks preparing a home’s garden and lawn. But is that even realistic for most of us?  Here are some tips on how you can achieve top-quality results in landscaping and curb appeal without spending lots of time to accomplish it.

Invest in Low-Maintenance Plants, Shrubs and Flowers

Depending on the position of your home you can plant things that do not require much attention. There are plenty of low, medium and high light plants and flowers that can easily function without much attention through an entire season. Some plants even work well with less water – ideal for homes in drier climates.

One easy to care for flowering plant is the daylily. These garden wonders are pest-free, cover a good amount of ground or border space, grow quickly and withstand both hot and cold climates. Colorful additions include plants like rhododendrons and peonies – both available in a variety of colors and each low-maintenance. Be sure to talk to a garden expert where you buy these plants to check on planting location for each.

For greenery and fullness you can add ferns – a plant that is available in thousands of varieties and very easy to care for. Perfect for shady spots in your lawn, ferns also do well in other parts of your landscape area without needing a lot of attention.

Arrange Colorful Patio/Porch Accessories

When you are done planting, the next thing you should do is to make sure the immediately visible exterior portions of the home and the driveway are both clean. A warm and inviting entryway will almost always attract buyers and entice them into wanting to explore behind the front door.

For inspiration, check out some of the home design magazines online or go window shopping online on websites such as potterybarn.com or pier1.com so you can see how their displays infuse bright colors in a warm and inviting way. You don’t have to go all out and spend too much money – just enough to add some dimension and interest to the space. Just one chair with colorful cushions, bright flowers in a striking planter and a topiary or two might be all you need. Of course you also want to invest in a brand new welcome mat that literally welcomes buyers into your home.
~
Enhancing curb appeal does not have to break your back or your bank – but by spending just a little bit of time you can spruce up your place enough to make buyers head your way rather than to the neighbor that does have a green thumb and plenty of time!

link.title: No-Hassle Curb Appeal For People That Don’t Have Lots of Time

entry.title: Important Safety Tips for Your Home While You Are Enjoying Vacation
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Leaving on vacation always make me think about safety issues that I must address at my own home before packing the family up for a fun vacation.

With summer fast approaching, you might already have vacation on your mind...so I wanted to share with you on this little video clip my favorite safety tips. In fact, I have multiple critical steps to prepare your home for safe keeping while you're away, to keep your nest safe and secure.

This is exactly what I did to prepare my home while I'm away in Florida:

The best way to keep your home safe in your absence is to make it appear you are home, leaving absolutely no clue you're actually away. Light, time and noise are your greatest weapons to accomplish this. Follow these tips to ready your home and keep it safe:

- Ask someone you know and trust to keep an eye on your house.

For short trips, ask one of your neighbors to pick up your mail and your newspaper. If you are going to be gone longer, however, be sure to stop by the post office and have your home mail delivery stopped until you return.

Be sure to provide neighbors, friends and family members with emergency phone numbers so you can be reached quickly. It's a good idea to leave a spare house key with a relative or neighbor as well.

- At least a couple of weeks before you leave for vacation, decide what to do about your pets. You may want to have a friend or neighbor stop by each day to provide food, water and exercise. Or you may want to hire a professional pet sitting service or take the pets to a reputable kennel. This decision should be made well in advance so that proper arrangements can be made.

- Use timers on lights, televisions and radios to provide sound and illuminate the inside of your home.

- If you still have a home phone, change the setting on your answering machine so it picks up on the first or second ring—or just turn down the ringer. A constantly ringing phone is also a good sign no one is home.

- For long absences, you may want to turn off the main water valve. This will help avoid problems with frozen pipes in winter and leaking pipes in the warmer months as well as other plumbing issues.

- Keep shades up and blinds and curtains open to make it appear you're home.

- Keep bushes and shrubs near your home's entrance and walkway well trimmed. This will eliminate hiding spots for burglars.

- Keep the outside of your home well lit. Burglars won't go where they can be seen.

- Ask a neighbor to park in your driveway, occasionally moving his or her car indicate your coming and going.

- Leave the air conditioner on. A silent compressor on a hot day is a good indication you aren't home.

- Have the lawn mowed my a friend or lawn service if you are away longer than a week in the warmer months.

- This one is tough for those addicted to Facebook but posting to Facebook where you are at all times you are not only sharing this with your 'friends'. Those posts and photos allow others to find out when you are away and where you are. This isn't as concerning when you are local as you could post a comment or photo as you are ON your way home or just arrived but when your, say, at Disney World, those with ill plans regarding your trip away from home.

- Be sure to turn down the temperature on the hot water heater and unplug televisions and other appliances. These appliances will be drawing electricity whether they are on or not. Unplugging them will help lower your electric bill.

- Turn your thermostats down (or up) before you leave. There is no reason to spend money heating or cooling the home when you are not there.

- Don't forget about the plants. If you are having a friend or pet sitter care for your pets, ask them to take care of your plants as well. Simply soaking the plants with water before you leave is not enough. A better idea is to create a self watering system if you cannot have someone care for the plants. For small plants, make a self watering system by filling a plastic container with pebbles. Then fill the bottom of the container with water. This allows the plants to slowly absorb the moisture they need, without the danger of their roots becoming waterlogged. Larger plants can be mulched with a damp towel or newspaper to prevent the loss of moisture.

- When the day to leave for vacation finally arrives, try not to make that departure too obvious to those passing by. If you have a garage, be sure to pack the car with the garage door closed. If you do not have a garage, you may want to pack a couple of items a day in order to avoid broadcasting to the world that your home will be unoccupied.

- This last tip isn't a security measure for your house but for your credit (you know I always care about that as well) as you need to keep tight check over your credit in order to purchase or refinance your home!

With all the excitement of the upcoming trip we sometimes get carried away, plan only for the trip and security of our home for while we are away and leave for our stress-free trip. But wait!! You suddenly realize the day before you return the date! You've missed your mortgage payment, car payment, credit card, and utility due dates by a week or more! This happens more than I'd like to hear and the credit company doesn't accept this as a viable hardship excuse. :-) So ensure you plan ahead. Go on and sit down to make all the payments needed to be made in advance before your trip and all those due up till a few days after your return for good measure to ensure you don't get tied up with the return home and forget this very important task to protect your credit rating!

As you can see, there is a lot to think about before you jump in the car or on a plane for vacation. Use this checklist as a way of bringing peace of mind to you and your family. Enjoy your vacations without worrying about the safety of your home while you're away.

As always, if you need anything from me, please don't hesitate to call or email!

link.title: Important Safety Tips for Your Home While You Are Enjoying Vacation

entry.title: What Determines the Value of Your Home?
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Basically, a home's worth is determined by its market value. How is "market value" determined? Most often, it's figured by a comparison ("comp") with homes similar to yours in the surrounding area. So, if the homes in your neighborhood average, say, $250,000, then it's likely that the value of your property will fall in the same range. But market value is also determined by a number of factors including the following: 

External Factors 

There can be several external factors influencing the value of your home. One is "curb appeal", or the first impression your property makes upon prospective buyers. A home that's in excellent condition on the outside will make a great first impression; a home in poor repair instantly loses its appeal to buyers. Other factors can include lot size, popularity of an architectural style of property, water/sewage systems, paved roads, sidewalks, etc. 
Internal Factors  

The condition of a home's interior also has a huge influence on prospective buyers. When you've demonstrated "pride of ownership" and kept up the maintenance (quality paint, trim, molding, etc.), a buyer's interest will immediately perk up for the simple reason that they know your care and concern will result in less cost and maintenance for them. Other internal factors include construction quality, condition of appliances, size and number of rooms, heating/cooling type, energy efficiency, etc. 

Supply and Demand 

"Supply and demand" simply refers to the number of homes for sale versus the number of buyers. When there are more homes than there are buyers, prices tend to be lower. When there are a lot of buyers chasing few homes, then prices tend to rise. In effect, supply and demand affects how quickly your home will sell. Location More than likely, you already know the old saying, "There are three main factors in real estate - location, location, location." While that's not the whole story, desirability is a big factor for home buyers. They may want to live in particular school district known for its education excellence…a great and safe neighborhood with rising property values…etc. 

But I Know My Home Is More Valuable Than a Lot of Comparable Homes in My Neighborhood  

Aren't Allowances Made for This? Definitely! Sometimes, it can be difficult to find homes exactly comparable to your own. So, dollar adjustments are made for the differences between your home and comparable properties. 

Where Do I Find Sales Comparison Information? 
The easiest source to access is your Realtor. After all, it's his or her business to know such information! But, there are also other sources you can tap into in order to get a complete picture of your home's value in comparison to others in your neighborhood. Here's an overview of them:

1. ) The Local Assessor's Office  

It's very likely that your local assessor will be able to provide the sales history of a particular house, neighborhood, or style of architecture. Many assessors also provide lists of recent sales which you can browse and compare to the assessment roll. Today, many municipalities provide local sales and assessment information online making it very easy to access. Check with your local government agency to find out if they provide this service. 

2.) Online Private Companies  

You can search for these companies using the Google search engine and the keywords "comparable home sales" or "comparable sales." Some companies offer free information; others charge a nominal fee. If you wish to get more specific, you can Google "real estate database" and type in the name of your particular state to get additional property information. 

3.) Your Local Newspaper  

It's likely that your local newspaper is a great source of specific real estate information. Look for quarterly sales reports in the real estate or business sections.

The Key to Getting the Price You Want (or Close To It) for Your Home 

The key to getting the best value is finding and matching the right buyer to your home. And that's the job of the Realtor! He or she should work hard to qualify those buyers upfront so the right people are viewing your property! In other words, the Realtor should weed out "lookers" and other unsuitable buyers as a first step in working with you. See how I do that for you by calling me today!

link.title: What Determines the Value of Your Home?

entry.title: World’s Top Speakers Address Top-Producing RE/MAX Agents in Sunny Las Vegas
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

Every year, Norine and I look forward to heading over to Las Vegas to join our favorite colleagues in learning the newest, latest and greatest techniques, tips and advice from the pros.  This year the International RE/MAX Convention was held at Mandalay Bay Hotel and Casino and it was a huge success!

Not only were there several amazing speakers present, all of whom gave us tremendous insight and experience but I was also honored to speak at the convention this year to share how our team successfully uses video in the business of selling real estate.  Here’s a rundown of what some of the other speakers had to say:

Customer Service is King

Nothing is more inspiring than to hear from the CEO of a company that registered a whopping nine hundred forty eight percent growth in just three years! That is a HUGE increase in growth of almost a 1000%!  Tony Hsieh, CEO of Zappos.com, talks about how he spearheaded the organization’s move into the mega millions success that it is today.  The one underlying fact he spoke to us about was his company’s “very best customer service” and how it changed the face of his company.  To me, that was further testament to the fact that our customers, our clients, our friends – are our most valuable assets in our organization.

Jump In Now, What Are You Waiting For?

World-renowned author David Bach addressed the group and shared a very energetic account of why real estate is definitely not in a bad place right now like many people like to think.  He points out that the market has gone up a very significant 100% in the last three years – something that mainstream media often neglects to report.  Keeping with very strong basic economic principles, David graphically (in a real fun way – watch the video) shows us that “real estate does not stay down”.  It comes back up, he says.  And he could not be more right about that.  I love the way he flippantly said “Hello??? You can buy houses below replacement costs now – what are you waiting for??”

If He’s Doing It, We Should Too

There’s a good chance that by now you’ve heard about Warren Buffett’s recent famous statement about the real estate industry being among the best asset class right now.  At our conference, one of the things esteemed life coach Tom Ferry mentioned was about Mr. Buffett’s declaration that he’d buy a hundred thousand single-family homes since they are such a great investment right now.  Very simply put, Tom said, “Is that a good sign – yes or no?”
~
Folks, living and breathing the real estate industry is what we do and we love our job!  For months now we’ve been raving about the amazing market out there right now and how you should buy a home today. This year’s convention in Las Vegas solidified our strong belief that this couldn’t be a better time to buy real estate.

We invite you to come in and meet with us – so we can collectively come up with a plan to get you into your first home, a better home or even your dream home.

link.title: World’s Top Speakers Address Top-Producing RE/MAX Agents in Sunny Las Vegas

entry.title: 2012 Is Going to Be An Incredible Year for the Louisville Real Estate Marketplace!
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

For many months now, we’ve been tracking buyer activity in the Louisville, KY area and it has been a great time for our marketplace!  Not only are we seeing a phenomenal turnout of buyers looking at new properties at the moment but also we have also just come out of a fantastic year with incredible sales figures from 2011 to show for it.

In fact, we have had so much positive activity that our team is growing – with an additional four real estate agents joining our team for 2012.  As your #1 full service Realty team in Louisville, we are ready to take on the marketplace and we are expecting a very big 2012!

Great Expectations for the Louisville Real Estate Marketplace in 2012

There’s no doubt about it – buyers are on the prowl and they are interested in some good deals on some great properties.  And this year we are going to make sure we do everything we can to make sure buyers (and sellers) have all the support they need to release all that pent up energy we’ve been seeing for so long.

Looking at the past several years, even though sellers are generally lacking confidence in the market (and our government) the news is not all that bad.  With about 7,000 homes currently listed as available inventory there are homes for sale for buyers to choose from.  Of course as we transition into the warmer months we expect to see greater inventory levels, further pumping up the supply and demand cycle.

There are several reasons for our housing market to continue to perform well; first, as an election year there will be heightened consumer confidence to support continued growth in home sales. Also, the fact that interest rates remain at their lowest ever in the history of mortgage lending.  And when you combine these two factors with home prices that are lower than we have seen in decades, it’s a recipe for success!

Increasing Buyer Activity Dominates the Market

Through our exclusive home search tools, LouisvilleHomeSearcher.com and LouisvillePropertyOnline.com, we are able to track just how many buyers are out there looking for new homes and the numbers are off the charts! In fact, we have never been busier in terms of buyer activity.  Not only are they anxious to get in on the action and seize the amazing opportunities out there with such low interest rates and housing prices, but we are also seeing a lot of families moving to the area.
~
Last year we sold fewer than 11,000 homes in the Louisville area and if our calculations are even close, the year we are seeing ahead promises to be even better!  To find out whether this is the right time for you to buy, sell or even if you just want to lurk the market and see what’s out there, contact us and give us the opportunity to show you why we’re the best at what we do!

link.title: 2012 Is Going to Be An Incredible Year for the Louisville Real Estate Marketplace!

entry.title: How to Make Money When Selling Your Home
entry.content:
Watch on your mobile device >>

I am about to share with you some of the best ways to improve your home which will allow you to make more money when you sell it. These tips have been proven time and time again, so let's get started!

First, curb appeal is critical. You want buyers to look at a home and see it as "move-in ready". When buyers see homes that need work, they will not value them as highly as a home that is ready for move in.

One thing that you should know if you ever watch HGTV is that kitchens and master bathrooms are the two areas of a home where you should invest the most money in renovations. By far, research has shown that buyers are most excited by updated and upgraded kitchens and master bathrooms.

Our client shown on the video did a great job with this by putting a lot of effort into making the kitchen really shine. One thing that they did was to install recessed can lighting. I would have also suggested that they put in wide beam halogen light bulbs which gives wider, bright light. Light means more space to a buyer which means more money for you!

They also painted using fairly updated colors. I would also suggest granite countertops if they wanted to invest more money. The trick is finding someone who has granite pieces as it can save you some cash.

Our clients also put in stainless steel appliances. That is the way to go for sure! Stainless gives a modern, updated look and doesn't cost that much more money to do.

In the master bathroom, let's begin with the double bowl vanity. If you are married, you would definitely want this.  Many married buyer couples love the double bowl vanities simply because the husband (or the wife) is a bit messier. So, each person wants their own sink!

This seller also put in a glass shower door, which is great. You could even look at a frameless glass shower door to get more bang for your buck.

They also updated the lights using stainless fixtures. They matched the hardware on the door and hinges.

As you can see, these are fairly simple and inexpensive “fixes” that you can do to a home to get more money out of it when you sell. For more tips and answers to your real estate questions, call us today!

link.title: How to Make Money When Selling Your Home

entry.title: Appraisers are tasked with correctly identifying m...
entry.content:
Appraisers are tasked with correctly identifying market value, which is defined commonly as typical buyer and seller with typical motivation (not an REO/foreclosure situation, for example), regular marketing time, etc..., regardless of the market.

If the market is in decline, that should be identified and handled in the analysis. If the market is improving, which is what we see in most of the Louisville/southern Indiana neighborhoods that aren't overrun with foreclosures, then we handle that appropriately in the analysis as well.

A good check is to look at list prices of homes, the list to sale price ratio and marketing time, all in comparison with the most recent sales prices. If listings are even with or slightly below sales prices, then generally that signals a decline. If the list prices are 10% over sales prices and typically sell at 5% under list, then that signals an increasing market.

The best advice I have, after 10 years in this business, is to talk to multiple agents and appraisers and be armed with facts. If a house on your street sold below market because of a divorce, let your appraiser and agent know that so they can tag that property as a possible non-arms length (remember 'not under stress') sale to remove from the analysis. This happens all the time.

I would invest in a pre-listing appraisal and a home inspection that you pay for. Don't wait until you have an offer on your house and get the borrower's appraisal and inspection back to find out there are problems.

Good luck-

Jason Ferris
Certified General Appraiser
Kentucky, Ohio, Indiana
